#Text=Wikinews interviews Spanish evolutionary biologist Francisco G. Gonzálvez
#Text=Wednesday , December 19 , 2012
#Text=a weaver ant , Oecophylla smaragdina , on a Singapore rhododendron Image : Francisco G. Gonzálvez .
#Text=A video of a Singapore rhododendron with a carpenter bee Image : Francisco G. Gonzálvez .
#Text=A video of a Singapore rhododendron with a Nomia genus bee Image : Francisco G. Gonzálvez .
#Text=A large carpenter bee with a small ant Image : Francisco G. Gonzálvez .
#Text=A weaver ant is " guarding " the flower Image : Francisco G. Gonzálvez .
#Text=A large carpenter bee Image : Francisco G. Gonzálvez .
#Text=In a study published on October 29 , Spanish researchers studied Singapore rhododendron interaction with ants .
#Text=The researchers discovered that the flower produces substances to attract weaver ants to drive away the smaller Nomia bees , which are a worse pollinator than larger carpenter bees .
#Text=The ants do n't drive away the larger bees , which pollinate the flowers and visit them more often as they get better .
#Text=Today , Wikinews interviewed Spanish evolutionary biologist Francisco G. Gonzálvez , one of the lead researchers of this study .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What prompted your curiosity in the rhododendron flowers and bees ?
#Text=Francisco G. Gonzálvez
#Text=:
#Text=I am an evolutionary biologist interested in how ambush predators on flowers , such as crab spiders , praying mantises or ants , can modify pollinator-plant interactions .

#Text=By doing field observations in Singapore I realized that the aggressive weaver ant , Oecophylla smaragdina , spent a lot of time on rhododendron flowers causing different responses in their floral visitors .
#Text=While the presence of the weaver ants on flowers deterred small floral visitors , large carpenter bees were unaffected by the presence of the ants .
#Text=Since then we conducted a number of experiments and observations to elucidate the role of the weaver ants , flowers visitors and the plant species in this complex system .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What activities did the study involve ?
#Text=Francisco G. Gonzálvez
#Text=: Mostly the study involved many hours fieldwork .

#Text=We quantified bee visit rates at plant with and without ant nests , assessed the pollination effectiveness of the different flower visitors , examined the association between weaver ant presence ant fruit an seed set and finally we tested whether weaver ants were attracted to flowers .
#Text=Additionally we developed a simple optimal-foraging model and compared its prediction with observed patterns .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What was the study timeline ?
#Text=What activity took the most time and attention ?
#Text=Francisco G. Gonzálvez
#Text=: The experiments and observations in field were conducted from April to June 2010 in MacRitchie Reservoir , Singapore .
#Text=However , the activity that took most time and attention was to determine pollen production per flower in order to evaluate pollination effectiveness of the floral visitors .
#Text=We spent almost two months counting pollen grains under a microscope .
#Text=It was definitely the most tedious part of our work .
#Text=( (
#Text=Wikinews
#Text=) )
#Text=What technology was involved in the study ?
#Text=Francisco G. Gonzálvez
#Text=: Basically it was an observational study so we did not use complex technology .
#Text=Probably the most sophisticated technology we used was the microscope under which we counted pollen grains .
